prompt: The Running Man is one of those films that if overwatched, would become boring and depressing even
answers:
The Running Man is one of those films that if overwatched, would become boring and depressing even more. Yet, seeing it in late afternoon late night television, and viewing it on a high school TV, was a real pleasure. How else could I tell you that it was entertaining?

The film begins with some serious philosophical and/or emotional problems. Then we get to the beginning point, which is the man who makes the most sense of his situation. You can guess the first sentence because the film starts off really smart. The man is trying to find out who he is, how he was able to make such a profound and important decision. He doesn't find it that way, but instead, he finds a way to solve the problems that he believes are his own by choosing to live a more meaningful life. In other words, after his mother died his father would come home and live with him. But, not only did his dad choose the life he wanted to have, his life became a complete fulfillment of himself, who in turn moved to Los Angeles to be with his stepmother. All through the rest of the movie the young man asks himself all sorts of questions to try to decide if he wishes to fulfill his destiny with someone else. If he ends up being a hero, then it's because he loves to ask the right questions
